title: كَأَيِّنْ وَكَذَا
description: Learn about كَأَيِّنْ (how many, variant of كَمْ) and كَذَا (such and such number) - special numeral expressions in classical Arabic with their grammatical rules.

notes.title: Introduction to كَأَيِّنْ
content: كَأَيِّنْ (also written كَائِنْ or كَأَيٍّ) is a classical Arabic word meaning 'how many' or 'many a.' It functions similarly to كَمْ الخبرية (the informative كَمْ meaning 'many') but with some grammatical differences.
كَأَيِّنْ is considered a كِنَايَة عَنْ عَدَدٍ (an expression standing for a number) - it indicates a large, unspecified quantity. It appears frequently in the Quran.
keyPoints: كِنَايَة عَنْ عَدَدٍ: stands for an unspecified number
Common in Quran and classical texts

examples.arabic: وَكَأَيِّنْ مِنْ نَبِيٍّ قَاتَلَ مَعَهُ رِبِّيُّونَ كَثِيرٌ
examples.english: And how many a prophet fought alongside whom many devout men (Quran 3:146)

examples.arabic: وَكَأَيِّنْ مِنْ آيَةٍ فِي السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ
examples.english: And how many a sign in the heavens and earth (Quran 12:105)
And how many a city We have destroyed (Quran 22:45)

examples.arabic: وَكَأَيِّنْ مِنْ دَابَّةٍ لَا تَحْمِلُ رِزْقَهَا
examples.english: And how many a creature does not carry its provision (Quran 29:60)

notes.title: Grammar of كَأَيِّنْ
content: كَأَيِّنْ is مَبْنِيَّة (indeclinable) - it doesn't change form. It typically takes a تَمْيِيز (specifier) introduced by مِنْ. The word after مِنْ is مَجْرُور (genitive).
Unlike كَمْ which can take its تَمْيِيز directly in the genitive (كَمْ كِتَابٍ), كَأَيِّنْ almost always requires مِنْ before its specifier.
keyPoints: Takes تمييز with مِنْ: كَأَيِّنْ مِنْ رَجُلٍ
Different from كَمْ which doesn't require مِنْ

examples.english: كَأَيِّنْ: indeclinable noun
How many books I have read (كِتَابٍ = تمييز مجرور)
How many books I have read (with كَمْ, no مِنْ needed)
And how many a city: قَرْيَةٍ is specifier

notes.title: كَأَيِّنْ vs كَمْ
content: Both كَأَيِّنْ and كَمْ الخبرية mean 'many a/how many' but differ grammatically. كَمْ takes تَمْيِيز مجرور directly or with مِنْ optionally. كَأَيِّنْ requires مِنْ before its تَمْيِيز.
كَمْ has two types: خَبَرِيَّة (informative, meaning 'many') and اِسْتِفْهَامِيَّة (interrogative, meaning 'how many?'). كَأَيِّنْ is primarily خَبَرِيَّة.
keyPoints: كَمْ: تَمْيِيز مجرور or with مِنْ optionally

examples.english: How many men I saw (كَمْ الخبرية, no مِنْ)
How many men I saw (كَأَيِّنْ, requires مِنْ)
How many men did you see? (كَمْ interrogative, نَصْب)
How many times I advised you

notes.title: Introduction to كَذَا
content: كَذَا is a word meaning 'such and such (number)' or 'so many.' It is used when the speaker knows the specific number but chooses not to mention it, or when indicating an approximate amount.
كَذَا can be used alone (كَذَا) or repeated (كَذَا وَكَذَا) for emphasis. It takes a تَمْيِيز (specifier) in the منصوب (accusative) case.
keyPoints: كَذَا = such and such, so many
Speaker knows number but doesn't state it

examples.english: I have such and such (number of) books
I bought so and so many pens
I walked such and such miles
Such and such men came

notes.title: Grammar of كَذَا
content: كَذَا is مَبْنِيَّة (indeclinable) and composed of كَ (like) + ذَا (this). Its grammatical position depends on context - it can be فاعل، مفعول به، مبتدأ, etc., always في محل (in the position of) its function.
The تَمْيِيز after كَذَا is مَنْصُوب (accusative), unlike كَأَيِّنْ which takes مَجْرُور with مِنْ. When repeated (كَذَا وَكَذَا), the meaning intensifies.
keyPoints: Takes its position based on function

examples.english: كَذَا: indeclinable substitute noun
I have so many dirhams: كَذَا is subject

examples.arabic: رَأَيْتُ كَذَا وَكَذَا رَجُلًا: مفعول به
examples.english: I saw so and so many men: object position
So many people came: subject position

notes.title: Usage in Classical Arabic
content: Both كَأَيِّنْ and كَذَا are features of classical Arabic and appear in Quran, hadith, and classical literature. Understanding them is essential for reading classical texts accurately.

In modern Standard Arabic, كَمْ is more commonly used than كَأَيِّنْ, but كَأَيِّنْ remains important for Quranic study. كَذَا appears in both classical and modern contexts when being deliberately vague about numbers.

examples.english: I gave him such and such dinars (deliberately vague)

examples.arabic: كَأَيِّنْ مِنْ فِئَةٍ قَلِيلَةٍ غَلَبَتْ فِئَةً كَثِيرَةً
examples.english: How many a small company has overcome a large company (Quran 2:249)
He prayed such and such number of rak'ahs (Hadith)

examples.arabic: فِي يَوْمِ كَذَا مِنْ شَهْرِ كَذَا
examples.english: On such and such day of such and such month

exercises.promptEn: كَأَيِّنْ takes a genitive specifier with _____

exercises.prompt: كَذَا تَعْنِي عَدَدًا مُعَيَّنًا لَمْ يُذْكَرْ، وَهِيَ كِنَايَةٌ عَنِ _____
exercises.promptEn: كَذَا means a specific number not mentioned; it is a substitute for _____

exercises.prompt: التَّمْيِيزُ بَعْدَ كَذَا يَكُونُ _____، مِثْلَ: كَذَا كِتَابًا
exercises.promptEn: The specifier after كَذَا is _____, like: كَذَا كِتَابًا

exercises.prompt: كَأَيِّنْ وَكَذَا كِلَاهُمَا اسْمَانِ _____ لَا يَتَغَيَّرَانِ
exercises.promptEn: كَأَيِّنْ and كَذَا are both _____ nouns that don't change

exercises.prompt: وَكَأَيِّنْ مِنْ قَرْيَةٍ - قَرْيَةٍ هُنَا _____ مَجْرُورٌ بِمِنْ
exercises.promptEn: And how many a city - قَرْيَةٍ here is a _____ in genitive with مِنْ

exercises.answer: How many, many a (indicates large unspecified number)
Such and such, so many (vague number reference)
A substitute expression for a number

exercises.prompt: A Quranic word meaning 'how many' that requires مِنْ before its specifier
A word meaning 'such and such number' when speaker doesn't specify
The grammatical term for the noun that specifies what is being counted
